metadata.case_name: Messrs. Ispahani Ltd. & Ispahani Employees Union v. Others

facts.text: Messrs. M. M. Ispahani Ltd. carrying on business in Calcutta since December 1934.
Shortly before partition, Messrs. M. M. Ispahani Ltd. transferred registered head office from Calcutta to Chittagong in Pakistan.
Messrs. M. M. Ispahani Ltd. became Pakistani company after August 1947, continued to own properties in India and small business in Calcutta.
Messrs. Ispahani Ltd. (company) incorporated on September 15, 1947, took over goodwill, trading rights, stock-in-trade, properties and assets of Messrs. M. M. Ispahani Ltd.
Most shares of company held by Messrs. M. M. Ispahani Ltd.; business same nature, same premises, same telegraphic address, same workmen on same remuneration.
Company paid puja bonus at rate of one month's wages from 1948 to 1952, even in years of loss.
Workmen under M. M. Ispahani Ltd. always got puja bonus at one month's wages; company did not deny this in reply.
No puja bonus paid in 1953, leading to dispute.
Dispute between company and workmen referred by Government of West Bengal to Second Industrial Tribunal on December 17, 1953.

Industrial Tribunal held: no puja bonus for 1953 as not established uniform rate for sufficiently long unbroken period; workmen entitled to count service under M. M. Ispahani Ltd. for benefits under company.
Labour Appellate Tribunal (July 27, 1955): puja bonus term of employment, entitled for 1953; no continuity of service from M. M. Ispahani Ltd., fresh employment.
When M. M. Ispahani Ltd. transferred to Chittagong, retrenchment of employees not willing to go; company employed those whose services terminated.
Employees agreed to termination with M. M. Ispahani Ltd., received provident fund settlement and arrears of salary; joined company after withdrawal of provident fund, no undertaking for continuity.
Employees joined provident fund of company afresh.

legal_issues.text: Whether workmen entitled to puja bonus for 1953 based on implied term of employment.
Whether workmen entitled to benefits for service rendered under Messrs. M. M. Ispahani Ltd. during service under company.

petitioner_arguments.text: Appellate Tribunal had no jurisdiction to interfere with Industrial Tribunal's finding of fact on puja bonus.
Even if jurisdiction, Appellate Tribunal's decision incorrect in law; no implied term for puja bonus.
Service under M. M. Ispahani Ltd. counts for benefits under company due to substantial continuity.

respondent_arguments.text: Practice under M. M. Ispahani Ltd. immaterial, does not bind company.
Termination of employment with M. M. Ispahani Ltd.; fresh employment by company.

court_reasoning.text: Decision on implied term of employment for puja bonus is mixed question of fact and law; Appellate Tribunal had jurisdiction.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Similar to custom, adverse possession, or joint family status.

court_reasoning.text: Tests for implied agreement from Mahalaxmi case: unbroken payment, sufficiently long period, not out of bounty. All satisfied here: paid 1948-1952 unbroken, even in loss years, since company's inception.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Length of period depends on circumstances; here justifies inference.

court_reasoning.text: Puja bonus in Bengal based on implied agreement or custom; here implied term category.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Tests from Mahalaxmi correct and followed.

court_reasoning.text: No continuity of service: employees terminated with old company, settled claims, fresh appointment by company, new provident fund.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Company took over business but employment fresh.

holdings.text: Workmen entitled to puja bonus at one month's wages for 1953 as implied term of employment established.
No entitlement to benefits from service under M. M. Ispahani Ltd.; fresh employment.

precedents_cited.case_name: Mahalaxmi Cotton Mills Ltd., Calcutta v. Mahalaxmi Cotton Mills Workers Union
precedents_cited.relevance: Laid down tests for inferring implied agreement for puja bonus: unbroken, long period, not bounty.

precedents_cited.case_name: The Millowners Association, Bombay v. The Rashtriya Mill Mazdoor Sangh, Bombay
precedents_cited.relevance: Full Bench formula for profit bonus; puja bonus stands on different footing.

outcome.summary: Both appeals dismissed: company's appeal against puja bonus award fails; workmen's appeal against denial of service continuity benefits fails.
outcome.relief_granted: Workmen entitled to puja bonus for 1953 at one month's wages; no continuity benefits.

key_quotes.text: We are of opinion that the tests laid down in that case for inferring that there was an implied agreement for grant of such a bonus are correct and it is necessary that they should all be satisfied before bonus of this type can be granted.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Affirms tests for puja bonus implied term.

key_quotes.text: The decision whether there is an implied term of employment is a mixed question of fact and law and not a pure question of fact.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: There was termination of employment of the workmen when Messrs. M. M. Ispahani migrated to Pakistan and the employment of the workmen by the company was fresh employment.
key_quotes.speaker: court
